title: China sends the fifth medical team to Samoa in 2021
description: On April 27th, 2021, China's fifth medical team to Samoa held a departure ceremony. The renewed medical team programs between China and Samoa started in 2018, and the rotation is typically every six month. The fifth team added Obstetrics and Gynecology and Critical Care Medicine specialists on its team. The team concluded its mission on February 26th, 2022 and returned to China. The mission was longer than expected because of the Covid-19 pandemic.   The personnel on medical team to Samoa was selected from various hospitals in Jilin province in northern China.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China sends the fifth medical team to Samoa in 2021

# Description
On April 27th, 2021, China's fifth medical team to Samoa held a departure ceremony. The renewed medical team programs between China and Samoa started in 2018, and the rotation is typically every six month. The fifth team added Obstetrics and Gynecology and Critical Care Medicine specialists on its team. The team concluded its mission on February 26th, 2022 and returned to China. The mission was longer than expected because of the Covid-19 pandemic.   The personnel on medical team to Samoa was selected from various hospitals in Jilin province in northern China.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services and medical assistance, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare specialists, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Samoa in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Samoa signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $16,436,000 ($13,506,000 in principal payments and $2,929,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 5-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’  The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI.'
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Samoa. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.2. The total estimated suspension amount in 2021 is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Samoa secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Samoa in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Samoa signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $16,436,000 ($13,506,000 in principal payments and $2,929,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 5-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’  The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI.'
justification: Debt suspension agreement is a financial arrangement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial obligations and COVID-19 response

title: China provides grant for Phase 5 of the China-Samoa Agricultural Demonstration Farm Project (Linked to Project ID#49231, #49190, #61281, and #61282)
description: On February 18, 2021, Chinese Ambassador to the Independent State of Samoa announced plans to build new agricultural infrastructure and 50 new demonstration farms in Samoa. More specific information was expressed by Li Zhiwen who is the head of the China-Samoa Agricultural Technical Aid group. He provided construction plans and details related to China's interest in pursuing the project. This project was known as the Samoa-China Agricultural Technical Aid Project (SCATAP).   On December 8, 2022, a handover ceremony was held for this project. The SCATAP Phase Five supports 58 model farmers with 30 in vegetables, 22 citrus and 6 chicken farmers.  Each vegetable model farmer received 2 x 30 x 6 tunnel houses with irrigation system, 50 trees citrus plantation for citrus farmers and a broiler house of 90 m fence for each chicken farmer. The donation also included a small-scale feed mill to make feed for poultry, pigs, cattle and fish farms.  The effort is part of the China-Samoa Agricultural Technical Aid project and is the fifth phase of that project. See project ID#49231 for Phase I, ID#49190 for Phase II, ID#61281 for Phase III, and ID#61282 for Phase IV.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China provides grant for Phase 5 of the China-Samoa Agricultural Demonstration Farm Project (Linked to Project ID#49231, #49190, #61281, and #61282)

# Description
On February 18, 2021, Chinese Ambassador to the Independent State of Samoa announced plans to build new agricultural infrastructure and 50 new demonstration farms in Samoa. More specific information was expressed by Li Zhiwen who is the head of the China-Samoa Agricultural Technical Aid group. He provided construction plans and details related to China's interest in pursuing the project. This project was known as the Samoa-China Agricultural Technical Aid Project (SCATAP).   On December 8, 2022, a handover ceremony was held for this project. The SCATAP Phase Five supports 58 model farmers with 30 in vegetables, 22 citrus and 6 chicken farmers.  Each vegetable model farmer received 2 x 30 x 6 tunnel houses with irrigation system, 50 trees citrus plantation for citrus farmers and a broiler house of 90 m fence for each chicken farmer. The donation also included a small-scale feed mill to make feed for poultry, pigs, cattle and fish farms.  The effort is part of the China-Samoa Agricultural Technical Aid project and is the fifth phase of that project. See project ID#49231 for Phase I, ID#49190 for Phase II, ID#61281 for Phase III, and ID#61282 for Phase IV.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and technical aid without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of agricultural infrastructure, demonstration farms, and support for model farmers in various agricultural sectors

title: Chinese embassy in Samoa donates USD 200,000 to the Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP) in Samoa
description: On November 17, 2021, the People’s Republic of China presented its yearly financial assistance to the Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP), the lead agency in the Pacific region for managing and protecting the environment. Chinese Ambassador, His Excellency Chao Xiaoliang, presented the annual financial assistance of USD 200,000 to the Director General of SPREP, Mr Kosi Latu, during a ceremony at the SPREP Headquarters in Apia, Samoa.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

# Title
Chinese embassy in Samoa donates USD 200,000 to the Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP) in Samoa

# Description
On November 17, 2021, the People’s Republic of China presented its yearly financial assistance to the Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP), the lead agency in the Pacific region for managing and protecting the environment. Chinese Ambassador, His Excellency Chao Xiaoliang, presented the annual financial assistance of USD 200,000 to the Director General of SPREP, Mr Kosi Latu, during a ceremony at the SPREP Headquarters in Apia, Samoa.
justification: Financial assistance to an environmental protection organization, but no direct energy transition impact
evidence: Donation to SPREP for general environmental protection purposes

title: Chinese Embassy in Samoa  donates a batch of Covid-19 pandemic materials to Samoa in December 2021
description: From December 9th to 10th, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Samoa and the Ministry of Health of Samoa jointly organized the Chinese medical team to go to Savai'i Island to carry out the free clinic activity of "sending doctors to the island". The Chinese medical team was the fifth Chinese medical team to visit Samoa (see project ID#93478). Ambassador Chao Xiaoliang and Minister of Health of Samoa Valesi attended the launching ceremony of the event, and donated a batch of anti-epidemic materials to the grassroots community of Savai'i Island in the name of the embassy. During the free clinic, the Chinese medical aid team provided free examination, diagnosis and treatment for 252 residents of Savai Island, and donated a batch of commonly used medicines to the local health center, which was warmly welcomed by the people.
combined_text:

# Description

The Chinese medical team was the fifth Chinese medical team to visit Samoa (see project ID#93478). Ambassador Chao Xiaoliang and Minister of Health of Samoa Valesi attended the launching ceremony of the event, and donated a batch of anti-epidemic materials to the grassroots community of Savai'i Island in the name of the embassy. During the free clinic, the Chinese medical aid team provided free examination, diagnosis and treatment for 252 residents of Savai Island, and donated a batch of commonly used medicines to the local health center, which was warmly welcomed by the people.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare assistance and medical donations without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of Covid-19 materials, free clinic activities, medical aid team providing healthcare services

title: China provides cash grant of $80,926 USD for the Guangdong (Huizhou) Friendship Scholarship to Samoa students
description: In 2021, China provides the Guangdong (Huizhou) Friendship Scholarship worth $80,926 USD to Samoa students. The scholarship program was implemented by Samoa Ministry of Education, Sports and Culture.

title: Chinese pathologist team provides technical assistance in autopsies to Samoan Ministry of Health
description: On April 29, 2021, a team of 8 Chinese forensic pathologists arrived in Apia Samoa to assist in the post-mortem examination of a backlog of 13 bodies that have been stored in the morgue for almost 1 year awaiting autopsies. The Chinese government provided the equipment for the post-mortem examination and also covered all the expenses including the autopsy, traveling, and accommodation of the Chinese forensic pathologist team, costing more than 500,000 Tala.    At the additional request of the Samoan government, the Chinese forensic pathologist team also conducted 3 more autopsies of current cases. The team also conducted two forensic technical training lectures at the invitation of the Samoa Police, including the crime scene investigation and the fingerprint application.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese pathologist team provides technical assistance in autopsies to Samoan Ministry of Health

# Description
On April 29, 2021, a team of 8 Chinese forensic pathologists arrived in Apia Samoa to assist in the post-mortem examination of a backlog of 13 bodies that have been stored in the morgue for almost 1 year awaiting autopsies. The Chinese government provided the equipment for the post-mortem examination and also covered all the expenses including the autopsy, traveling, and accommodation of the Chinese forensic pathologist team, costing more than 500,000 Tala.    At the additional request of the Samoan government, the Chinese forensic pathologist team also conducted 3 more autopsies of current cases. The team also conducted two forensic technical training lectures at the invitation of the Samoa Police, including the crime scene investigation and the fingerprint application.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare technical assistance and training, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Forensic pathology assistance, technical training, healthcare sector focus

title: Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of China provides the Juncao Technical Training Course at the China-aided Samoa Demonstration Farm
description: On February 25, 2021, the opening ceremony for the Chinese-funded Juncao Technical Training Course was held at the Demonstration farm aided by China. The training course received funding from the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of China and from the China-Aid SA Agricultural Technology Cooperation Project. The event marks the start of China-backed efforts to develop agriculture capacity in Samoa via the Juncao center. Chinese Ambassador to Samoa, Chao Xiaoliang, was present at the opening ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of China provides the Juncao Technical Training Course at the China-aided Samoa Demonstration Farm

# Description
On February 25, 2021, the opening ceremony for the Chinese-funded Juncao Technical Training Course was held at the Demonstration farm aided by China. The training course received funding from the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of China and from the China-Aid SA Agricultural Technology Cooperation Project. The event marks the start of China-backed efforts to develop agriculture capacity in Samoa via the Juncao center. Chinese Ambassador to Samoa, Chao Xiaoliang, was present at the opening ceremony.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural training and capacity building without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Juncao Technical Training Course, agricultural capacity development, food security focus

title: China sends the 17th medical team to São Tomé and Príncipe in September 2021
description: On September 17, 2021, the seventeenth Chinese medical team assigned to São Tomé and Príncipe departed China to fulfill their medical service of eighteen months. There were eight members of the team, including medical staff members from West China Hospital at Sichuan University, the Second West China Hospital of Sichuan University, and hospitals affiliated with Southwest Medical University. The team also had interpreters and cooks.  During their stay in São Tomé and Príncipe, the team diagnosed local residents, donated medical supplies including PPE, and provided training for local doctors. They covered nineteen medical rounds, covering a total of 1300 kilometers during their stay and serving more than 1400 people. The team further executed the "São Tomé Island Youth Dental Fluoride Project," which provided free oral examinations to more than 1,400 youths across eleven elementary schools. The medical team was expected to return to China on March 15, 2023.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China sends the 17th medical team to São Tomé and Príncipe in September 2021

# Description
On September 17, 2021, the seventeenth Chinese medical team assigned to São Tomé and Príncipe departed China to fulfill their medical service of eighteen months. There were eight members of the team, including medical staff members from West China Hospital at Sichuan University, the Second West China Hospital of Sichuan University, and hospitals affiliated with Southwest Medical University. The team also had interpreters and cooks.  During their stay in São Tomé and Príncipe, the team diagnosed local residents, donated medical supplies including PPE, and provided training for local doctors. They covered nineteen medical rounds, covering a total of 1300 kilometers during their stay and serving more than 1400 people. The team further executed the "São Tomé Island Youth Dental Fluoride Project," which provided free oral examinations to more than 1,400 youths across eleven elementary schools. The medical team was expected to return to China on March 15, 2023.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services and medical training without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare services, medical training, dental health project

title: Chinese embassy provides Christmas food packages of unspecified value to São Tomé and Príncipe for food insecurity relief
description: On December 15, 2021, Chinese ambassador Xu Yingzhen and Labor Minister of São Tomé and Príncipe attended a formal handover ceremony for a grant of Christmas food packages to São Tomé and Príncipe. The purpose of this grant was to provide resources to impoverished citizens of São Tomé and Príncipe. The packages included oil, rice, flour, and other items. The monetary value of the grant is unknown.
combined_text:

DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title

The purpose of this grant was to provide resources to impoverished citizens of São Tomé and Príncipe. The packages included oil, rice, flour, and other items.
